Received two orders of our app, and had to ask the server to remove the charge for the second one after the check was delivered. Food delivery was very slow, even after the server told us "it will be here in two minutes". When pizzas finally arrived, they were warm . . .not hot.

1RUff9LBn0D8FPm57kZYQg.text: After an amazing ballet performance at the Royal Opera House in Covent Garden, Fire & Stone pizza restaurant was just steps away to feed our hunger. It looks elite even from the outside and as we enter a waitress kindly asks us to wait a couple of minutes for her to check if there are any available tables. The restaurant has two floors -there's plenty of room so we are shown to a table on the upper floor. Everything seems to be exquisite -the decor, the layout, the menu, the waiter, perfect compliment for a night out at a theatre or the opera. I'm not feeling out of the place with my elegant little black dress. The delicious, stone-baked pizzas are sorted -in continents -love the idea! You can find sortiments of Pizza Deluxe (Paris, Brittany, Queenstown), then there they come -Africa, Asia, Americas, Australia, Europe -with different cities included. Ingredients are well listed so you can make a decision where you want to taste-travel. I experimented with Casablanca and I was enjoying every bit of it. Impressive bar, they serve cocktails as well. Not the cheapest place to go to but once in a while each of us deserves a treat. Not to forget, they offer theatre deals -which inlcudes dinner & tickets to top West End Shows. Culture and cuisine -good match at any time!

_1pfEb852KczbVkH9Ig3bA.text: I've been to this place 3 times now and have been more disappointed each time. The first time I went was ok, staff were a little disinterested but everything came and was nice. The second time I went we were waiting for a little while even though we'd booked a table, but were seated and everything seemed to be fine. However my companion's pizza arrived along with another one which wasn't the one I ordered, turned out the chef had read the ticket wrong, so it took about 20 mins for the correct one to be cooked. Fine, mistakes happen, however I was sitting with an empty glass and wasn't offered a drink or anything to be going on with. The main thing we noticed was that they don't push drink on you, so if you have an empty glass they won't ask if you'd like another drink or some water, and it's quite hard to catch the attention of waiting staff. So they took 10% off the final bill, however forgot to take the voucher we had off the bill so it took them a while to sort that out. The third time I went was a disaster, we arrived in time for our booking, we were told to wait up by the bar, so we did. While we were standing at the bar we were not offered a drink or even acknowledged by the plenty of bar staff who all seemed to be standing around not doing much. After a few minutes, a massive hoard of people descended on us so there were far too many people standing at the bar and it was starting to irritate some of the diners whose tables were close to the bar. We were approached by one of the hosts who asked us if we had a booking, so we said yes, in this name for this time, she looked as if she didn't believe us and said that she would have to go and check. So off she went. By this time it had got well past the time that we should have been seated so we stopped a waitress who was imensely rude, who said I'm not a host, I just work on the floor, I can't help you. We then asked if she could find someone who could and she didn't even respond to that, she just walked off. So we went and found one of the hosts who eventually seated us, we were left with a waiter who just wasn't interested, clearly didn't want to be there and wasn't bothered whether we enjoyed our meal or not. We finally got our meal a long time after we were seated, it had got so late and we'd been there for so long that I got half-way through my pizza and decided that I just couldn't be bothered any more. As per usual we weren't asked if we would like any more drinks. Nearby tables were not cleared and left with dirty crockery all over them. So we didn't leave a tip (even though they add an OPTIONAL 12.5% on before they total up the bill, WATCH OUT FOR THAT) and a waitress who hadn't dealt with us asked us why, and we told her. Hopefully our comments will be passed on Also they had a large party coming in so were moving tables with the maximum amount of fuss and noise and even asking diners if they would move It's a shame because the food is good, however the disinterested and frankly rude and disorganised waiting staff offer very poor value for money, in my opinion. I won't be going back unless I'm told by someone I trust that the staff have improved.

Jt8WwUJwOVJxklfYAUv2Ig.text: The food here is absolutely delicious. I am a huge fan of pizza and the variety on the menu is great. The place itself is very impressive and when you walk in take a moment to take it all in. I recommend looking out for the special deals as it can be a bit expensive to eat here.

nH0nyMK_djc34zNEs1mhfA.text: I like the idea of this place, gourmet pizza styled after some of the worlds most famous cities, the menu is packed with mouth-watering options, toppings you would never think of, like roast lamb and potatoe, it can be very difficult to pick from the huge selection, however both times I have been the pizza has been just a little disappointing, maybe there is a reason most people stick to the usual toppings? Unfortunately it's a case of them sounding better than they actually are. I would still recommend checking this place out though, the food is still good and its interesting! Its also very well priced for central London. The restaurant its spacious, comfy and at the very least its something different.

d4JjjkNvLs0h9F0xEJxEXw.text: I think this is one of those hidden gems in Covent Garden. Somewhere that is Stylish, well laid out, Roomy (rare for Covent Garden) and good value! Have been plenty of times now and it doesnt disappoint. The Gourmet pizzas I think are different and interesting. Only thing that lets it down sometimes is the Service which can be a bit strange.

Qpd-woHtVfWHMAzLu6C8xg.text: Entering fire and stone is almost walking into an industrial age, with gleaming steel everywhere you look, the huge pizza oven raising up from the ground floor like a chimney, and sparse uniformed tables stretching out to the far back wall.This large restaurant isn't particularly intimate, but for fans of pizza it's an intriguing place to go, and has great deals for penny saving nights (and days) out.My favourite pizza here is the Lombok, it's like eating an oriental fusion meal on a pizza, which is a little hard to comprehend but it's an amazing taste sensation.Check out their website for fab deals such as pizza and wine for £10, and more. Just around the corner from Covent Garden, it's a great way to eat close to the market without the spine chilling prices of those eateries. I recommend taking a bunch of friends here for a get together, but make sure you have a good plan of action for ordering, as sometimes the service can be a bit hit and miss.

aPGkPWwd0Vx_JcC3BKPV8Q.text: I had heard great things about this restaurant but was disappointed to be honest. The pizzas were okay but a bit messy - the duck salad started was delicious though. We went on a Saturday so it was busy and they wanted a party of 12 people to be in and out in two hours. We felt rushed and that the service wasn't really up to scratch. It was hard to get hold of a waiter and our cocktails took ages to arrive.

iPMi1_9rRZOWmyo1rfMFig.text: Had a decent meal here on a special discount price deal through lastminute.com. The pizza toppings are all very interesting, though some seemed a bit too 'out there' for me. I chose a Ko Pha'gnan pizza which was basically thai green curry flavour with sweet potato and sweetcorn. It was really tasty and interesting and came very quickly. However it was very hot and had a little too much chilli on it for my taste. Our waitress was very helpful and brought us tap water without a grimace ( unusual for London). The restaurant itself has quite a buzz, its light and clean, but a little noisy.All in all very good value ( even with the deal) as you can eat an main course with a glass of wine for just over £10. Would recommend it if you're in the area, but nothing to step out of your way for. There are more exciting places to go.

tMk2YNpzvXpngx2YFtG-AQ.text: This is a great restaurant in Covent Garden and handy for pre and post theatre dinners - watch out for combined dinner and theatre ticket offers for this restaurant. The staff are friendly and the menu is good with plenty of choice of traditional Italian food. It can get busy at wekends and in the evenings and is worth booking a table in advance.

7tEGIG_bHtUWtsBMvpsRLw.text: The service in this place is terrible. But it's great if you want somewhere a bit trendy to go and eat decent pizzas. Just be prepared to experience snooty waiting staff and intermittent attention.

jwEpsV9PLNIFn9-5dIewlg.text: Fire and Stone's eclectic menu of pizzas from around the world is original and delicious. The prices are fantastic for a Covent garden venue (you can usually find good booking deals on lastminute.com, too!). It can get very crowded, so book in advance and expect slow service at times. The starters are okay - I recommend the combo mezze platters - but I've always been too full to try dessert. My favorite pizza is the Moroccan one with lamb and minted yoghurt - divine! Wine list & drinks are reasonable, but cocktails are pricey! Fantastic atmosphere - always buzzing.

Tq4ka_aIPnr6Tk29Mvkm_g.text: The pizzas are amazing and the variety of toppings is incredible. Try the 'Camberra' or 'New York' - they were my favourites! Roast potatoes on a pizza?!! Even my friend who is the fussiest person in the world (doesn't eat cheese amongst many other things) was happy! We went before the theatre and have gone back several times - each time the service has been quick, food fantastic and reasonable in price! Recommended 100%!

nMmDwLWsG6cz2R8g_9xe5Q.text: We found and booked the 2 for £10 deal through their website. They had a lot of unusual selection of pizzas, I chose New Foundland pizza which was topped with salmon flakes, rocket, salmon caviar it was certainly new for me and delicious!The place was spacious, the atmosphere relaxed and though the service was a tad slow at times, they arrived quickly when asked. We were initially billed at full price but when we pointed out the offer we came for, the amendments were made promptly and pleasantly. Overall, we had a good evening and it was a nice end to the weekend.

m3TpycVM3VzLfsG7liP1hw.text: Fire and Stone is a great place to eat and socialise. Great atmosphere and delicious range of pizzas. The pizzas are creative, some very unusual flavours that work well together. Loads of variety, original toppings and good portions! They seemed under staffed and service was slow but friendly enough. Will definitely go back.

xO77F-IjXfxzqktBOijuXA.text: Nice and trendyI booked online which more than useful !!Great feature!

Uma15Acd1lQqFeuwlGBjWw.text: If you're a fan of well priced stone baked & wood fired pizza then this is the place! Great value for the covent garden area - they more often than not have discounted offers being diplayed outside or online. Large restaurant with an upstairs & downstairs dining areas. The queues to get in at night on weekends can be long & slow - even with a reservation! A number of times we've had to wait for our table to be available - despite arriving on time for the reservation. The pizza menu is large with a lot of choices on offer. Once seated have always found the waiting staff to be polite & attentive despite being so busy. Thumbs up - it's not fancy by any means but good value food in a nice enough environment all the same!

Df67rQaRV5jjiA8l4F6ASw.text: The pizza bases were nice and the flavour combinations interesting and a refreshing change from the normal bland pizza types. The pizza I ordered had way too much sweet chilli sauce on it though which was disappointing. The service was ok - we didn't book and got a table quickly, but the room was incredibly noisy and we were unable to hear each other without yelling. Ok for a quick meal but I can make better pizza myself.

hV1d3BL16iQDc7Fbip_nXg.text: I went to the Fire & Stone for a meal on a hen night. There were 16 of us and the waitress made us feel really welcome. The restaurant is roomy and inviting and has sturdy chairs, which is great when you are on the larger side. We had a three course set menu for £14.95 which I thought was fantastic value for money. Starter was breadsticks with dips and olives. I had the Canberra pizza which I thoroughly enjoyed. Dessert was ice-cream which was rich and refreshing. We had a fab night and I would definitely go back again when next in the area.

uIpenwt__Ij8ajORse3kCg.text: I can't be the only one to think that duck, hoisin sauce AND mozzarella is just plain wrong..., found the toppings too complicated and why is a pizza topped with rosemary infused mascarpone, garlic mushrooms and roquefort blue cheese (sic)and walnuts inspired by Casablanca. I chose this one and I wasn't transported to North Africa - far too greasy and rich. The bases though are pretty good. However they must be doing something right as it was packed when we arrived. Service charming and efficient, reasonably priced wine.

MBrzhlj1UuErt-2VziUTlg.text: A comfortable arrangement of soft and hard seating with super efficient waiting staff who were attentive and pleasant, good wine list and delicious pizzas to delight you.

yMW65-RN4sAlKk_v5pwfjQ.text: Wow! I was amazed at how good the Pizza was here and I can say without a shadow of doubt that it was genuinely the best tasting Pizza I have ever eaten! They have a real range of cool Pizza's - I got the Bombay style which included tandoori chicken strips and mango chutney on it. Really such a treat.

i_h0MWT52-MtwUTBvhHIxA.text: Fire and Stone offers some great lunch time deals if you happen to work around the area, with a pizza and a beer or wine costing only £5.50. They sometimes have other offers though the prices are still fairly reasonable even if you're paying full price. I like to think that their pizza is much better than those served at many of the chains, although they do have some unusual combinations named after large cities around the world. The restaurant looks very impressive because their extra tall ceilings make the dining room feel extremely large and open. Unfortunately the only downside is that sometimes a few of the tables are too close together and you end up overhearing other people's conversations.

W1X4JJZooM06Gsyrt0tepA.text: This is one of the best places I've found to go that doesn't cost much but still feels like you're treating yourself. I've eaten here a few times - on a date, with a few friends and with a big group of people. Each time I've had nothing bad to say about the service. I wouldn't rave about it (they don't make any special effort to be friendly) but I haven't had a bad experience yet. The decor is hard to describe. Efficient maybe? It's modern, with lots of steel, but the soft lighting makes it quite comfortable and mellow somehow. Upstairs is definitely better than downstairs as the ceiling is a lot higher. and there seems to be more space between tables. And the pizzas are amazing. They range from quite simple through to basically a meal complete with potatoes on a pizza base. Every one I've tasted I have liked so far. And the two hour time slot? Who takes that long to eat a pizza?

J_5t70DxpfNqGvTG7-BPAg.text: I won't go on about the amazing pizzas here as everyone has already listed their favourites (although how can you not love the concept of rosemary roast potatoes on a pizza?). I personally liked the decor, the huge wood fired oven which spans across the two floors is an interesting and functional feature and the atmosphere is comfortable and relaxed. The service may be a little slow on occassion but hopefully this is a sign of the rapid success of the restaurant and they will get to grips with the huge demand soon, ideally by opening many more branches, with one next to my house preferably!

UL5oIt-UaKOtvC_w-f8Ifw.text: Great place! I was there two weeks ago, and it was so fantastic. At the Covent Garden tube station a men gave me a leaflet with fire and stone advertisement: 2 pizza for 10 pound. very cheap! My girlfriend ordered some noodles with mushrooms. She said: the best I've ever hadAnd the Woman, who seated us was so amazing beautiful! I was not able to look somewhere else :-)This place is brilliant!!!!

wykp_Q_P_VdHJTQaLZNulw.text: The food is ok, more tomato base needs to be used and the cheese is sparse.

e5LDct4nAlDJnQIs9mBvsw.text: I would definitely not recommend this place for birthday parties. After my experience here, I would not recommend this place at all. The Covent Garden Fire and Stone has a decent menu, and is in a good location. However, the prices are not that cheap. You are essentially paying more for weird toppings, some of which sound good but don't taste good. Then everything you ask for is extra. Parmesan on your pizza? £1 extra. Want to exchange a topping on a pizza for something else? You have to pay for the extra topping even if you are swapping say, duck for tomatoes. After a few of these issue came up, we starting to feel ripped off. The waiters constantly pushing for us to buy extras, or buy a more expensive wine, or bottled water instead of tap did not help at all. Then came the 'icing on the cake'. We had brought a birthday cake for our friend, and asked if they could light the candles and bring it out etc. They told us this was no problem, however there would be a £3 charge per head to do this!! For our large group, this would have added about £45 onto the bill. A restaurant more interested in getting maximum money out of tourists than keeping their customers happy. For the same money, you can do a lot better than this in Covent Garden. Avoid!

GV0PQfAfd4hCfSIS_qDAPQ.text: If value, atmosphere & quality pizza is what your looking for Fire & Stone have it covered. The pizzas are among the best I've eaten, you'll find some interesting combinations of toppings amongst the more common types. Be sure to order some extra 'toppings' (only £1 each) they come as dips rather than actually on the pizza, and taste great - particularly the chilli jam. Offers are often available on voucher websites.

1c8IpmmBzFfpppJjFqmXAw.text: A great place to try something different. It's not that quiet/intimate so going as a couple isn't great but if you can go as a group and get one of the larger tables it's a bit nicer. Service is good and the restaurant looks great; the range of gourmet pizza is pretty extensive so there should be something for everyone (though most people stick to steak options). Your pizza comes piled high with toppings and salad and all of these pizzas go great with a glass of wine. They have some good discounts and pre-theatre menus and I would recommend going off peak to get a table. Their lunchtime deals are really popular but worth queuing for!

JSPOTkyQX0hcNhZy3mDWqQ.text: I have visited Fire and Stone 3 times now and certainly wouldn't hesitate about going back!It is very central - perfect for the threatre district and it is also very cheap for London (they always have deals on for £8 for a pizza and a drink).There pizzas are lovely - very thin and tasty with a twist on the 'normal' pizzas that you would expect. They have toppings like roast potato and duck, they are all named after either countries or cities.The restaurant itself is very modern, they have a pizza oven from the basement up to the roof - very effective.Lovely place all round.

glr4TJtlj-D4ohYwaISg5A.text: This place seems to be getting mixed reviews, but I think it's awesome. There's a pizza to suit everyone's taste and it's got a great atmosphere. Sure, the service could be a little better, but for such an amazing location I can forgive them for this. If you are thinking about going to Fire & Stone, do check their website and Toptable for special offers before you book (and it is worth booking). Most times I've been there I've taken advantage of the two pizzas for a tenner offer, which is massively reasonable for such yummy grub, although it is only valid on certain nights and at certain times.

PeRREOdjkfJc6d7vZ1s9OA.text: For me, this was just an overblown and overpriced Pizza Hut. None of the promised italian pizzeria charm, and nothing that justified its much higher price tag. I had visited Fire and Stone because I had heard it was more of an authentic experience, and because I wanted to taste wood fired pizza's to see if they really were superior. perhaps it is just my taste, but there wasn't much of a difference to me! The food was hot and served in a timely fashion, and it wasn't horrible - but not as good as expected, and not what I had hoped for. the service was a little brisk, although it was very busy with passing trade and pre-booked theatre offers. I probably wouldn't visit again, but I suspect that they were not aiming this restaurant at me anyhow!

z894hxqpbgDXPsK8TXF4zg.text: Exciting pizza. I had the Byron Bay and R had the Cairo. R nailed the secret. The cornmeal in the crust totally enables the exotic ingredients- aka my sweet potatoes. Kids liked the seats and the kids menu. Clearly - to me - the place to eat when at Cov. Garden

fT6merPqLTCxOM0t7QOUNw.text: Love it, love it, love it! I grudgingly tell you about this place, as part of me wants to keep it to myself... Fire and Stone is the perfect answer to your indecision about what cuisine to have - you can have them all! All of their pizza toppings are themed by continent and all are delicious.. Some of the toppings seem a bit out there for the less adventurous, but trust me, just dive in! The wine list is not extensive, but there's a decent enough choice. The ambiance is great here too - the place looks like the set of Sex and the City (try to go with 4/5 people as you can get a great booth!!) and there's a giant pizza oven at the front of the shop. Service is a little hit-and-miss, but everything else outweighs that. Do expect, however to be politely asked to finish up if you exceed the 2 hour limit - but hey, it keeps the cost down! Pricing is equivalent to another, more generic, pizza place on the high street - but that's where the comparison ends...

fu-koZZkooiUtk-4KYtM3A.text: Only Fire & Stone could put bacon & black pudding on a pizza and make it work. Favorite pizza place HANDS DOWN!

jUyV9RK8m6eZxiQr7GkuwA.text: The key with Fire & Stone is that if you're intending to go there around a traditional mealtime, for heaven's sake make a booking first. It's usually pretty busy, and the ad-hoc booking arrangement when you get there is a little confusing (and has lost many customers to the adjacent GBK). Once you're in though, you'll learn the art of originality in the pizza medium. Whilst pizza joints using high-quality fresh ingredients aren't exactly hard to come by in London nowadays, few exhibit the raw creativity that Fire & Stone demonstrate. There's a real joy in ordering something which you don't normally find on a pizza, and is exactly why the Bombay (tandoori marinated chicken, yoghurt, broccoli, red onion, mango chutney, and so on), the Peking (hoi sin duck, cucumber, spring onions), Jakarta (satay chicken, aubergine, red chilli, tomato chutney) and Melbourne (brie, butternut, red onion, pumpkin seeds) are such amazing taste experiences. Personally I'd advise against the more traditional-looking pizzas, because you'll just find yourself silently cursing that you hadn't asked for the duck one after all. And also  buy the grilled bruschetta. Not negotiable.

J6BqB5JnVBrk2Gkxzr9gPQ.text: The pizza's here aren't your usual margheritas' and Hawaiian's  they are really interesting, fusion toppings from the corners of the globe. The menu does seem to change every so often too even more of an opportunity to try some unusual combinations. One word of warning however is that they aren't keen on letting you chop and change your toppings. The seating is in the form of big long benches (Wagamama style) which makes this place a good venue for a group outing. The staff are friendly but sometimes a little slow due to understaffing and last but not least the prices are good, very good! -With extra deals on their website too if you're organised!

BOQ6wUGdPqlCbXojhOI7jQ.text: Nice place. Bustling when I went there. Friendly, chatty staff and quick service. They didn't let us have a booth although there were half a dozen free and they didn't get used for the duration of the meal. Anyway the pizzas were good. Paid an extra £1.25 for the thin and crispy base. Really tasty. Had the Thai yellow curry, needed a little something on a pizza base. Could have been seasoned a bit more, but still good. The pizzas are freshly made and the bases are very nice cooked in some sort of hot stone gigantic oven which is quite an architectural feature of the restaurant. There is bound to be something for anyone. There are more than 25 or so very different pizza toppings with international themes. Also there are pastas.

ubhxWCkqkHIuImG5ZwRC4g.text: There are more Pizza Express, Strada and Ask restaurants in London than you can shake a stick at, and Fire and Stone is a wonderful alternative to them. The pizzas are fresh and delicious (the toppings will be like none you've seen before) and the service is pretty good. As with most restaurants, the markup on drinks is a little eye-watering, but the food is extremely competitively priced. The one unfortunate drawback is that it's regularly offered on the theatre and dinner deals favoured by websites such as lastminute.com, so getting a table without a reservation can be next to impossible at peak times. When the restaurant gets busy it's also pretty loud (although nothing compared to the cacophony of a Pizza Express).

wAbhEgwUb0dZgHxLn-0OgQ.text: I love Fire & Stone! Rather than your boring old Margarita or meat feast, you can chose from different styles of pizzas from all around the world, eg, Moroccan, Australian, Chinese. My personal fave is the New York, with bacon, sour cream and mini roast potatoes. It can get rather crowded due to it's popularity, and if you want to eat on Fri or Sat, you MUST book in advance. The best bit is that they have a permanent 'two pizzas for £10' offer on; to get it you have to book in advance via the special offer section of its website. Unlike some restaurants' special deals, this seems to be available everyday, as long as you book in the morning before you go.
